title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Changes in legal contexts ‚öñÔ∏è

EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation

"The data subject shall have [‚Ä¶] access to the personal data" (¬ß Art. 15, 1)
"The controller shall provide a copy of the personal data" (¬ß Art. 15, 3)

According to ¬ß Art. 20, users must receive their data "in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format" (¬ß Art. 20, 1)

üëâ Solution: Platforms offer data download packages (DDPs), which users can request and download to inspect data.
üëâ Consequence: Researchers uses DDPs as part of user-centric data donation studies.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
What are data donation studies?
üí° Definition: Data donation studies are a user-centric method for collecting digital traces.

Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.
They can make their data download packages (DDPs) available to science, often in the context of web surveys.
Researchers use CSS methods to filter, anonymize, and aggregate this data locally on participants‚Äô devices.
Participants can inspect/delete their data before any data is transferred.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: Which types of data do DDPs contain?
text:
Which types of data do DDPs contain?
For platforms like YouTube, Instagram, or LinkedIn, for example‚Ä¶ (Hase et al. 2024)

User profiles (e.g., privacy settings)
Activities (e.g., friends, likes, searches, exposure, analog movements)
Content and context (e.g., ads watched, algorithmically inferred interests)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to APIs (Ohme et al. 2024)‚Ä¶

Control & informed consent of users
Longitudinal data without "rate limits"
Partly additional measurements (e.g., exposure data; non-public data)

üëâ but can be burdensome for participants!

Using data donation to understand digital behavior.

title: What do people do online?
text:
About the workshop

üíª Workshop as part of the SPP Annual Meeting
üìÖ 22nd October 2025
üìç LIfBi Bamberg
Workshop led by Frieder Rodewald (University of Mannheim & Institute for Employment Research) - frieder-rodewald.de - and Sebastian Prechsl (Institute for Employment Research & LMU Munich) - iab.de
Part of the DFG project ‚ÄúIntegrating Data Donations in Survey Infrastructure‚Äù (see project website)
Based on a workshop at the CompText 2025 in Vienna (with Valerie Hase)

Further literature

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
üîë Key decisions

Which theoretical questions do I want to answer?
How do I operationalize key variables via my data donation tool?
How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Decisions we took









Goal: Feasability to implement data donation in a labor market panel, develop best-use practices, and understand non-response bias
Issues: Data availability, low response rates and bias (e.g., (Keusch et al. 2024))

Behavioral intentions as "willingness to donate" high (79-52% of survey respondents)
Actual behavior as "participation in data donation" low (37-12% of survey respondents)
Well known intention-behavior gap; where ü§ë seems to help (Kmetty et al. 2025)

Sample: A non-probability panel (online access panel)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Survey

Survey concerning‚Ä¶

online platform usage (YouTube, Instagram, and LinkedIn),
labor market characteristics,
and common indicators for non-participation.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: üõ†Ô∏è Strategy to make the extraction work
text:
üõ†Ô∏è Strategy to make the extraction work

Take a look at the DDP; download it, best for multiple time periods and for different languages
Understand the structure of the JSON or CSV.
Get an example file running.
Write the code for the extraction script.
Test your script, first locally and then in the wild.
Adapt your script.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
üö® Key issues (Hase et al. 2024)

Missing documentation by platforms (e.g., file structure)
Sudden changes in DDPs
Differences across languages & devices
Insufficient in-tool classification (e.g., LLM integration)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Example: Extract list of subscriptions

subscriptions.csv (before processing)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
üìö Workshop Takeaways

There are many ways in which researchers can learn about people‚Äôs online behavior through digital trace data
People can request, download and finally donate their (anonymized) data form most online platforms
Data donation can be burdensome for participants
Data quailty heavily depends on the platform and what kind of data you extract from participants

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: EXTRA: Can I extend the data?
text:
EXTRA: Can I extend the data?

Manual annotation by participants during data donation
APIs/scraping to extend collected data
Text-as-data methods for classification

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
EXTRA: Errors in representation
For example ‚Ä¶

Coverage error: Who is (not) represented in the sampling frame? (e.g., social media users vs.¬†YouTube users)
Sampling error: Who is (not) represented in the sample? (e.g., non-probability samples)
Non-response error: Who does (not) want to participate in the data donation?
Compliance error: Who is (not) able to participate in the data donation?

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Advancing the method

üì∏ Multimodal & cross-platform data (Wedel, Ohme, and Araujo 2024)
In-tool, local classification (e.g., local ML/LLMs?)
Workflow/UX-perspective

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Data as a political tool

Platforms do (willingly?) not provide data according to the GDPR/DSA (Hase et al. 2024)
The EU has started to sanction platforms like X/TikTok
DSA may become the subject of larger geo-political debates with the USA (Seiling, Ohme, and De Vreese 2025)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: üöÄ Can we improve & apply the method?
text:
üöÄ Can we improve & apply the method?

Can the method actually be applied for empirical research? (few examples, like (Thorson et al. 2021; Wojcieszak et al. 2024))
Requires interdisciplinary perspectives (e.g., addressing bias, integration in probability-based panels)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Who are you?
Please raise your hand ü§ö if you ‚Ä¶

are familiar with the term digital trace data
have worked with APIs
have worked with data donation
have worked with automated content analysis
regularly use programming languages (e.g., R, Python)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
About me: Frieder Rodewald
üéì PhD, University of Mannheim & Institute for Employment Research
üßê Research interests: "I study what people do online."


More info: github.com/frodew & frieder-rodewald.de

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
About me: Sebastian Prechsl
üéì Postdoc at Institute for Employment Research & LMU
üßê Research interests: Social inequalities (in the labor market), potentials of digital trace data for labor market research

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: What is the goal of this workshop?
text:
What is the goal of this workshop?

‚úÖ Understanding digital data traces as a type of data
‚úÖ Understanding data donation as a method of data access
‚úÖ Working through key steps of data donation methods (participant & researcher view)
‚ùì Discussing when (not) to use data donation studies
‚ùå Detailed implementation (e.g., server set-up, coding data extraction scripts)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
What is digital trace data?
üí° Definition: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena.
This might include:

Tweets, likes, shares on social media
Geo data (locations, movements)
Digital payments
Spotify playlists

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: Where can we find/collect digital trace data?
text:
Where can we find/collect digital trace data?

Apps (e.g., running apps)
Social media platforms (e.g., Instagram)
Payment systems (e.g., Paypal)
Wearable devices (e.g., smart watch)


Depending on the data collection method‚Ä¶ (Ohme et al. 2024):

Often fine-grained (e.g., time-stamped)
Often longitudinal (e.g., over years, within-individual change)
Often less reactive (e.g., less concerns about social desirability)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Which (latent) constructs can we measure?

Internet use (Parry et al. 2021) related to ‚Ä¶

Well-being (Ohme et al. 2024) or voting (Bach et al. 2021)

News engagement (Reiss 2023) related to ‚Ä¶

News diversity (J√ºrgens and Stark 2022) or public opinion formation (Yan, Schroeder, and Stier 2022)

Movements related to ‚Ä¶

Mobility during pandemics (Li et al. 2021) or social networks (Sepulvado et al. 2022)



ü§î How many minutes a day do you use the internet to consume news?

"Internet"?
"News"?
"How many minutes"?

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)

Self-reported data subject to specific bias (Scharkow 2016; Parry et al. 2021)
Response rates in surveys are declining (Luiten, Hox, and de Leeuw 2020)

Availabillity

Cheap (e.g., via APIs)
Large data sets ("big data")

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
(Dis-)advantages of digital trace data

‚úÖ More fine-grained, often longitudinal measures due to timestamps
‚úÖ Partly measurement of new variables (e.g., algorithmic inference)
‚ùå Bias due to errors in representation and measurement
‚ùå Implementation can be expensive and cumbersome
‚ùå More data does not mean better data!

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods

Platform-centric (based on platform cooperation)

API (J√ºnger 2021)
Cooperation with platforms (Wagner 2023)

User-centric (based on user cooperation and informed consent) or "follow the user" approaches (Caliandro 2024)

Data donation (Carri√®re et al. 2025)
Linkage (Sloan et al. 2020)
Sensors (Struminskaya et al. 2021)
Tracking (Christner et al. 2022)




Restrictions of platform-centric methods

Discontinuation of APIs
Concerns about bias

User-centric methods become more popular, given ‚Ä¶

Changes in law that enable such studies (GDPR, DSA)
Presumably (!) less biased data
Ethical considerations (informed consent)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Changes in legal contexts ‚öñÔ∏è

EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation

"The data subject shall have [‚Ä¶] access to the personal data" (¬ß Art. 15, 1)
"The controller shall provide a copy of the personal data" (¬ß Art. 15, 3)

According to ¬ß Art. 20, users must receive their data "in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format" (¬ß Art. 20, 1)

üëâ Solution: Platforms offer data download packages (DDPs), which users can request and download to inspect data.
üëâ Consequence: Researchers uses DDPs as part of user-centric data donation studies.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
What are data donation studies?
üí° Definition: Data donation studies are a user-centric method for collecting digital traces.

Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.
They can make their data download packages (DDPs) available to science, often in the context of web surveys.
Researchers use CSS methods to filter, anonymize, and aggregate this data locally on participants‚Äô devices.
Participants can inspect/delete their data before any data is transferred.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: Which types of data do DDPs contain?
text:
Which types of data do DDPs contain?
For platforms like YouTube, Instagram, or LinkedIn, for example‚Ä¶ (Hase et al. 2024)

User profiles (e.g., privacy settings)
Activities (e.g., friends, likes, searches, exposure, analog movements)
Content and context (e.g., ads watched, algorithmically inferred interests)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to APIs (Ohme et al. 2024)‚Ä¶

Control & informed consent of users
Longitudinal data without "rate limits"
Partly additional measurements (e.g., exposure data; non-public data)

üëâ but can be burdensome for participants!

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Our Agenda

frodew.github.io/workshop_spp_annual_meeting/

1Ô∏è‚É£ What is digital trace data?

2Ô∏è‚É£ What is data donation? - The participant‚Äôs perspective.

3Ô∏è‚É£ What is data donation? - The researcher‚Äôs perspective.

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Who are you?
Please raise your hand ü§ö if you ‚Ä¶

are familiar with the term digital trace data
have worked with APIs
have worked with data donation
have worked with automated content analysis
regularly use programming languages (e.g., R, Python)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
About me: Frieder Rodewald
üéì PhD, University of Mannheim & Institute for Employment Research
üßê Research interests: "I study what people do online."


More info: github.com/frodew & frieder-rodewald.de

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
About me: Sebastian Prechsl
üéì Postdoc at Institute for Employment Research & LMU
üßê Research interests: Social inequalities (in the labor market), potentials of digital trace data for labor market research

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: What is the goal of this workshop?
text:
What is the goal of this workshop?

‚úÖ Understanding digital data traces as a type of data
‚úÖ Understanding data donation as a method of data access
‚úÖ Working through key steps of data donation methods (participant & researcher view)
‚ùì Discussing when (not) to use data donation studies
‚ùå Detailed implementation (e.g., server set-up, coding data extraction scripts)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
What is digital trace data?
üí° Definition: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena.
This might include:

Tweets, likes, shares on social media
Geo data (locations, movements)
Digital payments
Spotify playlists

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: Where can we find/collect digital trace data?
text:
Where can we find/collect digital trace data?

Apps (e.g., running apps)
Social media platforms (e.g., Instagram)
Payment systems (e.g., Paypal)
Wearable devices (e.g., smart watch)


Depending on the data collection method‚Ä¶ (Ohme et al. 2024):

Often fine-grained (e.g., time-stamped)
Often longitudinal (e.g., over years, within-individual change)
Often less reactive (e.g., less concerns about social desirability)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Which (latent) constructs can we measure?

Internet use (Parry et al. 2021) related to ‚Ä¶

Well-being (Ohme et al. 2024) or voting (Bach et al. 2021)

News engagement (Reiss 2023) related to ‚Ä¶

News diversity (J√ºrgens and Stark 2022) or public opinion formation (Yan, Schroeder, and Stier 2022)

Movements related to ‚Ä¶

Mobility during pandemics (Li et al. 2021) or social networks (Sepulvado et al. 2022)



ü§î How many minutes a day do you use the internet to consume news?

"Internet"?
"News"?
"How many minutes"?

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)

Self-reported data subject to specific bias (Scharkow 2016; Parry et al. 2021)
Response rates in surveys are declining (Luiten, Hox, and de Leeuw 2020)

Availabillity

Cheap (e.g., via APIs)
Large data sets ("big data")

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
(Dis-)advantages of digital trace data

‚úÖ More fine-grained, often longitudinal measures due to timestamps
‚úÖ Partly measurement of new variables (e.g., algorithmic inference)
‚ùå Bias due to errors in representation and measurement
‚ùå Implementation can be expensive and cumbersome
‚ùå More data does not mean better data!

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods

Platform-centric (based on platform cooperation)

API (J√ºnger 2021)
Cooperation with platforms (Wagner 2023)

User-centric (based on user cooperation and informed consent) or "follow the user" approaches (Caliandro 2024)

Data donation (Carri√®re et al. 2025)
Linkage (Sloan et al. 2020)
Sensors (Struminskaya et al. 2021)
Tracking (Christner et al. 2022)




Restrictions of platform-centric methods

Discontinuation of APIs
Concerns about bias

User-centric methods become more popular, given ‚Ä¶

Changes in law that enable such studies (GDPR, DSA)
Presumably (!) less biased data
Ethical considerations (informed consent)

title:
What do people do online?
Using data donation to understand digital behavior.
